item.title: Overridden method
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

Object.toString();

/** * Returns a string representation of the object. In general, the * <code>toString</code> method returns a string that * "textually represents" this object. The result should * be a concise but informative representation that is easy for a * person to read. * It is recommended that all subclasses override this method. * <p> * The <code>toString</code> method for class <code>Object</code> * returns a string consisting of the name of the class of which the * object is an instance, the at-sign character `<code>@</code>', and * the unsigned hexadecimal representation of the hash code of the * object. In other words, this method returns a string equal to the * value of: * <blockquote> * <pre> * getClass().getName() + '@' + Integer.toHexString(hashCode()) * </pre></blockquote> * * @return a string representation of the object. */ public String toString() { return getClass().getName() + "@" + Integer.toHexString(hashCode()); }

basically what i want to do is, [tt]System.out.println(super.toString());[/tt], but with reflection.

Read full topic

item.title: Overridden method
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

just tried and it didn’t work, is there any other way?

[code]import java.lang.reflect.Method;

public class Test
{
public Test()
{
try
{
Class<? super Test> cls = Test.class.getSuperclass();
Method meth = cls.getDeclaredMethod(“toString”);

		System.out.println(meth.invoke(this));
	}
	catch(Exception e)
	{
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
}

public String toString()
{
	return "this one";
}

public static void main(String[] args)
{
	new Test();
}

}
[/code]

^printed “this one”

Read full topic

item.title: Overridden method
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

is it possible via reflection to run an overridden method form the super class of a class?

for example :

Class<? super SomeClass> cls = SomeClass.class.getSuperClass(); Method method = cls.getDeclaredMethod("someMethod"); method.invoke(instanceOfSomeClass);

would that call the original method and not the overridden one?

Read full topic
